chunks.text: Richard Borgens (1946–2019) was a prominent figure in the field of bioelectricity and its role in regeneration and developmental biology. His work significantly advanced our understanding of how electrical signals influence cell behavior and tissue patterning.  Borgens pioneered the use of applied electric fields to stimulate regeneration in damaged tissues, particularly in the nervous system. His research explored the mechanisms by which endogenous bioelectric signals regulate cell migration, differentiation, and growth, paving the way for novel therapeutic approaches to treat injuries and birth defects.
chunks.chunk_summary: This section commemorates Richard Borgens (1946–2019), a pioneer in bioelectricity research, highlighting his contributions to understanding how electrical signals influence regeneration and development.

chunks.text: It is an honor and privilege to celebrate the life of Richard Borgens whom the biology field in general and the bioelectricity field in particular lost in 2019. During his lengthy and remarkable career, Richard made numerous contributions to the study of endogenous bioelectric fields and their roles in development and regeneration. He was a prolific and tireless worker, producing a steady stream of important articles across the 1970s and subsequent six decades. He published some of the best functional data showing that endogenous transepithelial electrical gradients were important for limb development and regeneration.

chunks.text: Going further, he characterized the role of bioelectrics as instructive influences in repair and as a coordinate system in brain development. An important aspect of Richard's work is that he always paired his rigorous basic science with a strong effort to translate it to biomedicine. He was especially interested in neural regeneration, such as spinal cord repair, and treated numerous dogs with spinal cord repair strategies in his veterinary applications. On a personal level, Richard Borgens was one of the reasons we got into bioelectricity.

chunks.text: Michael Levin. I discovered his inspiring work as a high-school student. His clear writing, remarkable results, daring hypotheses, and artistic figures made the field irresistible to many. One of my all-time favorite science moments was that when I was able to invite him to visit my new laboratory at Forsyth Institute in 2001 (see photo). Meeting him in person was everything I had hoped for.
chunks.chunk_summary: The author reflects on their early encounter with Michael Levin's work and the impact it had on their career path.

chunks.text: He was not only brilliant and insightful, but also gracious, funny, supportive, and encouraging to me and my postdocs. He even sent us a whole box of electrical stimulation equipment, to assist our fledgling efforts. He was a colorful and complex man, and a great scientist. We are still citing his articles in our latest study, and expect to do so for a long time to come. He will be greatly missed.
chunks.chunk_summary: The author highlights Michael Levin's personal qualities, scientific contributions, and lasting impact on their own research.

chunks.text: Ann Rajnicek. Richard was inspirational in my formative years as a PhD student at Purdue University. He constantly challenged me, whether it was hitting a softball straight toward my position in short center field or by asking those difficult questions as a member of my PhD examining committee. Although I still cannot catch a high fly ball, he helped to shape my idea of what scientific enquiry should be; that it should question dogma as a route to innovation and that it should be incredibly, incredibly exciting.
chunks.chunk_summary: Richard's mentorship during the author's PhD at Purdue University instilled the importance of challenging dogma and pursuing exciting, innovative scientific enquiry.

chunks.text: I channel his bubbly enthusiasm whenever I do public outreach of science events or when I discuss his studies on spinal cord injury in my undergraduate teaching. His influence continues in ways he could not have imagined.
chunks.chunk_summary: Richard's enthusiasm and influence continue to impact the author's work in science communication and undergraduate teaching, particularly when discussing his research on spinal cord injury.

chunks.text: The Purdue University College of Veterinary Medicine mourned the loss of Dr. Richard Borgens, a retired faculty member and pioneer in paralysis research, who passed away on November 25 at age 73. Dr. Borgens earned his PhD in developmental biology at Purdue in 1977 and, after postdoctoral work at Yale and research positions in California and Maine, returned to Purdue as a faculty member. He established the Center for Paralysis Research and held joint appointments as the Mari Hulman George Professor of Applied Neuroscience and professor of biomedical engineering. He also co-founded and served as chief scientific officer for Andara Life Sciences, Inc.

chunks.text: A leading researcher in spinal cord neuronal regeneration, Dr. Borgens played a key role in developing Ampyra, a drug for multiple sclerosis. Purdue researchers developed the initial concept and conducted early animal studies at the Center for Paralysis Research, with the first clinical trials in paraplegic dogs taking place at Purdue's College of Veterinary Medicine.  Dean Willie Reed praised Dr. Borgens's passion and dedication to finding new treatments for paralysis and neurodegenerative diseases.

chunks.text: In 2006, Dr. Borgens received the Outstanding Contribution to Scientific Commercialization Award from the Indiana Health Industry Forum (IHIF).  Beyond his scientific pursuits, he was a passionate musician, originally trained in classical guitar and a member of various bands. He also had a keen interest in history and enjoyed collecting and restoring cars and antique firearms. A tribute to Dr. Borgens was held at Columbian Park in Lafayette on December 4.
